ref.mixed-citation: See Oies' Honchar, Sobor (Toronto, 1968), 227. The novel appeared in Ukraine in 1968 and was translated into English in 1989; see Honchar, The Cathedral, trans. Yuri Tkach and Leonid Rudnytzky (Philadelphia, 1989). All in-text page references are to the above Ukrainian edition. All translations are mine unless otherwise indicated.
Paul Ricoeur, "Rhetoric—Poetics—Hermeneutics," trans. R. Harvey, in Rhetoric and Hermeneutics in Our Time: A Reader, ed. Walter Jost and Michael J. Hyde (New Haven, 1997), 62.
Marharyta Malynovs'ka has also noted that Volod'ka's "loud phrases increasingly diverge from deeds." See M. Malynovs'ka, "Zhyttia v romani," Literaturna Ukraina, 19 January 1968, 2.

As levhen Sverstiuk has noted about this social type, "He likes to counterfeit words, juggle them, creating a brilliant display, a temporary illusion of truth." See Ievhen Sverstiuk, "A Cathedral in Scaffolding," in Clandestine Essays, trans. George S. N. Luckyj (Cambridge, Mass., 1976), 19.

For a discussion of these issues, see Ian Angus and Lenore Langsdorf, "Unsettled Borders: Envisioning Critique at the Postmodern Site," in The Critical Turn: Rheto- ric and Philosophy in Postmodern Discourse, ed. Ian Angus and Lenore Langdorf (Carbondale, 111., 1993), 5-13. See also Dennis J. Ciesielski, Between Philosophy and Rhetoric (New York, 1998), 18-28.
Francis J. Ambrosio, "Gadamer, Plato and the Discipline of Dialogue," International Philosophical Quarterly 21, no. 1 (1987): 21.
See Ciesielski, Between Philosophy and Rhetoric, 68; Régine Robin, Socialist Real- ism: An Impossible Aesthetic, trans. Catherine Porter (Stanford, 1992), 85-90.

Gadamer's notion of standing warrant for truth is lucidly discussed in Ambrosio, "Gadamer, Plato and the Discipline of Dialogue," 17-32. The open questioning and searching through dialogue necessary for standing warrant for truth are perforce limited by the constraints of Soviet politics. Honchar finds an opening, however, by avoiding ideological issues typical of many socialist realist novels and raising humanist issues that at least allow his characters to search and wonder on a more personal level.
